author: A_Brickset_user
title: Worth buying multiples of!
review:
This set is great....nice green pieces, castle walls, corner castle walls, forestmen figures!  I have at least 3 of these already.

The only thing I don't like about this set is it seems so small! If only there was more space inside! I guess that's one reason to buy more than 1 of this set, but on it's own it's a great stand alone set.

author: Novelty
title: Tree citadel
review:
This tree seems to be a bigger version of 6054, with the exception that it is set in the middle of a river/lake/moat and is thus surrounded by water.  The accessway to the fortress is via a bridge which seems to be of a rather simple design.  However, the columns and pillars besides it, adorned with the shields with the forestman emblem is intruging.  There's also a working porticullis which can be raised or lowered from the roof, akin to most castle sets of yore, but again this is a simple affair that is unadorned and simple.

The fortress itself isn't anything to marvelled at... it consists of 4 levels - water level, 2 floors and the roof.  The inside of the fortress can be accessed by swinging open the back which is connected to the rest of the fortress by hinges.  There's not much to see inside, besides a hidey hole for the treasure chest.

The set also suffers from the black tree trunks that's common to all forestman sets... and the plain blue baseplate also doesn't lend itself to the imagination.  Good small parts include the archery target on the shore and the winch to raise or lower the porticullis and the extra gold lion soldier.

author: StormSworder
title: Forestmens' finest.
review: I'm sure this set was never released in the UK, as I'd never seen it before, but I managed to track it down on e-bay.  This is a fantasic model, the kind of thing medieval adventures with Robin Hood and secret hideouts really are made of.  The set is built in the middle of a river/lake, contains a jail which looks half or partially submerged, a back which opens up, a working drawbridge and portcullis, battlements, a barrel raft and plenty of opportunities for alternative building.  The gem of the forestmen series.

author: hustla187
title: Why Bad Reviews?
review: The Forestmen sets were so good that they should all be rereleased. I like the forestmen hats and the shields with the deer on it which you don't see often. This set is nicely well built and yet you can still play with this. I really like the fortress and it has water around it except for a little bridge. The Forestmen were an amazing theme, and this is the reason why.

author: _obelix_
title: Forestmen's Coolest Set
review:
I've just recently acquired this set and i have to say its amazing... It took me some time to put it together but the final result was worth it. A full covered fortress with a small dungeon, draw bridge, and sliding door, raft, treasure 6 minifigs, all of which a man can only wish for. Plus, the whole fortress is covered with leaves and brunches, which gives it a true camouflaged look, which i think is pretty cool and well combined.

Again 5 out of 5.

author: AETerry
title: Forestmen's River Fortress Review
review:
If I have to pick and choose which of the Foretsmen sets were the best, I'd have to say it was this one.

 

For starters, the set is based on a blue base plate, clearly indicating a river or lake locale for the Tree-Fort. The Fort itself has a small draw bridge to make it harder for Knights to get to and attack and the Forestmen can easilly defend it. The back of the Fort build swings open to allow for access to inside and play. Tree branches and elements on either side make it look as if they've built their Fort from the inside of a tree.

 

There's a small tree on the bank with a printed target piece for target practice. A very well designed river raft and treasure chest feature in this set. There's a pair of the uncommon Forestmen Shields with stags.

 

For those who collected up the Forestmen sets, this set was just great to have.

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Perfect Ruin
review:
My god, I think this cost me £11 - £13, an impulse buy surprised by its being marked down. I would never have bought it otherwise. Extending the Forestmen collection did not seem justified at the time but this is more a model thats a very worthwhile purchase for Castle in general and just happens to be occupied by merry men. I felt it suits a lake better than a river but either way its a bit of an ancient ruin.

Minifigures:

[··][··][··][··]

  • The grey stave or lance for combat or boat steering.
  • Stag's head shields.
'Little John' and other characters are not clearly defined but merely hinted at, the above piece being a possible prop. The most like Robin Hood in the green shirt with pouch and belt gets a medium red feather this time, he's armed with a sword. Blue arm and chemise green top establishes different characters and the brown hats with small and medium yellow feathers makes pleasant variation, one of the wearers getting a spear. Bows and quivers otherwise equip most merry men. I often detail specifics of minifigures but its not important, especially here where the feather wheel sprues and various tops allow you to vary the characters how ever you want them for your set. We see here that the Black Falcons cease being the only enemy, perhaps the Lion Knights hold all the wealth.

Barrel Boat
First up a brilliant little barrel raft can be made using sideways building even though the top plate is precariously on only two studs but strong technic axles link the barrels up. A man with a stave is placed on top to steer it on the water and a brown chest full of yellow gold pieces can be transported across along with people. A sword also clips usefully on to the side.

Watery Grave
Out on the pond slant bricked tree roots and stone foundations are arranged opposite a tiny strip on green plate land. The trees corner slants look particularly good. A secretive open arch is built around the back for covert raft hiding while the front is much more built over. Five black singular bars are placed in a row in the middle like a sinister cage, this is not looking good for someone. Various tiles and a hinged brick suggest the access available and then the sinister watery dungeon is confirmed: a lone Lion Knight guard is imprisoned standing in the water. Grim. A sword is clipped inside for poking him aside a grey plate floor and then hinged black drawbridge that reaches the shore, not really necessary for a more defensive 'reached only by boat' design but this extra function is much fun and always welcomed by interactive children.
That covers the sinister water torture dungeon section and if it were on a river, flash flooding would quickly drown the prisoner. This is why an AFOL mind is not always helpful when reviewing a toy but children are not dumb and will often see abnormalities.

Overgrown Tower

Its quite grand this build and include various diagonal panels, black for tree and grey for stone, on the corners making a nicely shaped cross section. A very large area of tower wall and thick tree trunk is made completely separately so it can fit on to the hinges and slide across the tiles for access. That poor prisoner looks like he is being built over in the instructions! Here rather strangely arches come across back to front and make a more skeletal stone structure central to the building. It denies a middle floor and yet fills the gap where play takes place. These buttresses can be played in its just an unusual play interior when opened up but how about that, all the Forestmen sets are closed up in this way without open backed dead space. Smart arched windows style the front and dark grey stone prints improve the panels. The drawbridge gets a grand pillared and built arch entrance and the roof is completed with a winch and string operated portcullis in long black tiles. This smoothly drops down to securely lock out an attack and is a great element of the overall model. A spear is also clipped up here, weapons always clipped nearly everywhere in Castle for impromptu fighting. An offset side studded brick is built unsymmetrically at the front to add foliage and there is plenty more and a vine added around the many arched branches to make a good visual impact. A hinged brick holds a red and white double flag to show off who has captured the tower and the merry men's shields smartly adorn the front posts. Meanwhile a tree has grown on the bank and holds the smart archery target.

Alternative Building

The other builds shown are not too bad with another castle style tower in a lake and a long fortified bridge not managing to better the main design or add much more to the concept. The trees are so a part of the structure, they are not easily made separate but I could envisage one large tree being built with one decent castle or tall tower. 

Capture The Flag
The top has some decent battlements and you could point out some strange design choices in the build such as the back to front interior structure cluttering a better used space or the slants on the ground floor that just sit there without obvious purpose but I think this is nitpicking. The odd interior structure is well made with arches and the whole model has a great feel of age and abandonment to it. Not obviously a merry men's typical dwelling place, as opportunists they just happened to have moved in and taken command and this is where it best succeeds as a play ruin or lake tower for any characters in Castle scenarios. Like many model castles you can just replace the shields with any others you like and make changes to the design and so its a wonderful and unique model for the subtheme but especially the Castle landscape and play.

author: SirSven7
title: Lego Steve's Review
review:
Now we come to the largest of the Forestmen’s sets; their Fortress, I loved the way this set was fully enclosed and yet could be opened from the back and accessed, I also loved the small raft made of barrels and the little tree at the front with a target on it, plus you have to admire the bravery of the lone Crusader assaulting the fortress.

Overall this is a nice set, I like that it’s on a blue baseplate, so that it feels like it’s on a river or surrounded by a moat (a reason to use boats for once) but the interior detail of the fortress is extremely lacking, there’s only a small platform for space and one little dungeon (submerged in the water), after that there is nothing else. A nice set, beautiful looking and full of figs, its just a shame these nothing to enjoy on the inside.

If you like this review or if you wish to see images of alternate builds for this set and other sets for this faction click on the link to find it and all reviews of the Castle sets

http://legosteveblog.blogspot.com/2011/10/lego-forestmen-sets-1987-1990.html

author: T79
title: Who likes red pants?
review:
Ok, that title is not really indicative but I really didn't like the lion knight here with his totally red pants. This was the biggest forestmen set and also the last one we got. If it is any indication to the fun factor, I could almost build the first row of bricks without the manual as the blue plate had changed colour and precisely showed the outline of those bricks and plates needed to start building the set.

Box/Instructions

No more box with my copy, at least the instructions are still there. Another A4 sized booklet but, in contrast to some other sets I reviewed, here the entire first and last page are taken up by pictures of the set and alternative builds, respectively. These alternative builds show a more 'standard' (i.e. less dilapidated) water fortress and a fortified bridge. Especially that last one is a nice idea, unfortunately it shows that the parts selection is less than ideal to execute it. However, something like #6075 Wolfpack Tower should be doable with the parts here. Strangely, no alternative big tree while there certainly are parts to do that. Maybe there was something like that on the box? (Edit: checking the internet I did find a picture of the box and there really is a big tree as alternative idea, if you can draw away your attention from the terrible example of eighties hair on that kid. I quite like another fortress shown with trees for towers, though.)

Parts

A typical forestmen selection: some grey bricks and panel walls for the stone construction, black arches and corner walls and green foliage for the trees. Since this set was the biggest one in this theme there's more of it than in any other, but nothing particularly special. The best parts are probably the big blue baseplate and the round archery target tile. However, when we got this we only had a couple of treasure chests and barrels so they too were well received. That's why we felt it was a pity all those barrels went into the raft's construction as this made them unusable for something else, plus the raft looked too good to disassemble.

Minifigures

This set supposedly being the big forestmen's fortress (with a piece count about 50% greater than #6066 Camouflaged Outpost), the occupants are rather low in number. In total there are five forestmen (#6066 had six!) and one lion knight. I've never been fond of this soldier, it's the only one we had with completely red legs and he just seems too red. Usually the hips were black and, as can be seen here, this makes a big difference. Another couple of forestmen wouldn't have hurt (even in place of the lone lion knight), though more importantly some extra supplies: three swords, two spears and two bows (ok, and one lance) is not too much for six minifigs. A few extra weapons and shields and also some more barrels or chests would have been welcome. In this set some forestmen use a medium plume and not the traditional small one, I guess this was done to cut costs by allowing lego to include two less plume wheels.

The build

A rather engaging build, starting with some black slopes used as roots for the trees which look really nice (if a bit symmetrical). I also like the arches on which the stone structure is built, although I would have liked at least the rear arches to create a bigger opening so the raft could enter the fortress even with chest and perhaps minifig as well. The front looks sufficiently detailed with the bridge leading up to some pillars (which really serve no purpose but to look good) and the entrance with a solid portcullis-like door. Especially the narrow windows with some green foliage between them over the entrance add a nice touch there. The rear is rather plain, just four grey, non-printed wall panels without something to break it up a little. This entire wall is constructed on hinges so it can open, allowing access to the interior. The building is topped off with a walled platform, the way this is constructed is rather novel but there are some small openings left in the parapet (in fact, at several points some gaps are left in which could have been easily filled or covered, probably another measure to cut costs as in the end most are not visible anyway). OSHA compliance was still something unheard of back then I guess :-). Finally the trees get several leaves to complete the look and a flag on top. Curiously up until then all forestmen sets had a single red flag while they have a red-and-white one here, or should I say gules and argent?

The completed model

It certainly looks the part: a somewhat deteriorated tower (whether the trees or the tower were first is left unanswered) surrounded by water. This was a first if I remember correctly, other castles had a drawbridge and could be inferred to be surrounded by a moat but here at least it was explicit. As mentioned earlier, the rear wall can swing open to reveal the interior so it's a shame that the interior is so bare it's almost not worth it to take a look inside. There is only an empty platform above the water with an almost random clip for a weapon. There is not even a second level while there certainly is room for that. Off on one side is the prison: a row of black antennae as bars which looks suitable secure if rather gruesome (the water level is high enough for the ground to be under water). If you are so inclined you can use this to have the poor occupant drowned with the rising tide, in our case usually the cavalry would show up in time though. It does raise the question why boats are needed at all if the water is only knee-deep. And again it is a shame the raft cannot enter under that rear arch.

Overall opinion

While not the best forestmen set it still is a fine addition to the theme. I think it is too bad that again cost-cutting measures left this fortress more bare than desirable but on the other side, I did not have to pay for this so my parents may have disagreed :-). And you can always add your own ideas to the interior if you wish (and have the extra parts). The kids are mightily impressed with it and that little raft is as exciting for them as it was for us 25 years ago! Now I'm just going to replace those red, red pants...
